titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko AAA.harrgust2
Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Valerie Vanden Bossche
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 216127

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-11-04T08:28-0500

did.unittitle: Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko
did.abstract: The Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko measure 34.2 linear feet and date from 1957-1986. The records document the case brought by the New York State Attorney General's Office as cross-petitioner to the case brought by Rothko's daughter Kate, against the executors of Rothko's estate, Frank Lloyd and the Marlborough Gallery, for mismanagement and self-dealing. There are also records related to Harrow's writings about the case. Lastly, included in the collection are materials relating to art law issues in connection with the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in 7 series.

list.item: Series 5: Miscellaneous Case and Post-Trial files, 1972-1984, undated
Series 6: Reference Materials, Notes and Writings, 1970-1986
Series 7: Metropolitan Museum of Art / Walter Annenberg Etc., 1971-1981, undated

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Gustave Harrow was a New York State Assistant Attorney General, and an adjunct professor in the Graduate Program in Arts Administration at NYU. Abstract Expressionist Artist Mark Rothko committed suicide February 25, 1970 leaving the bulk of his estate, including 798 paintings (the greater part of his life's work) to the Mark Rothko Foundation which he had created shortly before his death. His daughter Kate [Rothko Prizel] brought suit against the estate executors and Marlborough Gallery for self-dealing, fraud, and conspiring with Marlborough owner, Frank Lloyd to waste the assets of the estate. The state of New York Attorney General's Office, represented by Harrow, joined the case as a cross-petitioner on behalf of the people of New York's interest as beneficiaries of the charitable Foundation. The case resulted in the return of most of the paintings, the removal of the executors (accountant Bernard Reis, artist Theodoros Stamos, and anthropology professor Morton Levine), and a $9.2 million judgment against them and Frank Lloyd. The case had a lasting effect on laws dealing with artists' estates, and Harrow was instrumental in framing a bill that aimed at reducing fraud in the fine arts market. Harrow wrote about the Rothko Estate case in several articles and in the 1979 book Art, the Artist, and the Consequences of Rothko: Lasting Legal Impressions from the Estate of Great Artist.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center. Use of archival audiovisual recording with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice. Contact Reference services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko were donated to the Archives of American Art by Marilynn Karp March 23, 1996. Mr. Harrow had deposited the papers with Ms. Karp, a colleague of Harrow's at New York University where he was an adjunct professor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York State Attorney General Gustave Harrow's records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko consist of legal and other documentation of the state's case in connection with the Mark Rothko Estate and Foundation, from Surrogate Court through appeals, as well as from Harrow's writings about the case, both during and after the trial. Various trial documents include affidavits, briefs, EBTs (examination before trial) trial transcripts, motions, depositions, notes and clippings, and miscellaneous records related to the case and post-trial activities. Also found are reference materials, Harrow's writings in connection with the case.

Unrelated to the Rothko case are Harrow's research materials for possible legal actions by the state in connection with Walter Annenberg's proposed donation of a Communication Center to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and with other issues including donations, object authenticity and the Packard Collection.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Another small collection (11 items) of Mark Rothko papers were loaned to the Archives for microfilming on reel 3135. The papers were in the possession of George Carson, husband of Rothko's ex-wife Edith Carson. Carson gave the papers to the Mark Rothko Foundation and gave the Archives of American Art permission to microfilm them. The microfilm is available at Archives of American Art offices and through interlibrary loan but are not described in the container listing of this finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Among the holdings of the Archives of American Art are the Mark Rothko Foundation records, 1976-1987; Legal records relating to Richard Serra v. United States General Services Administration et al., 1985-1987.

The Archives of American Art interviewed multiple artists as part of the Mark Rothko and His Times Oral History Project. Many of the interviews reference Rothko and his work, and relationships with the artist.
The Legal records relating to Richard Serra v. United States General Services Administration et al., 1985-1987 contains documentation of another lawsuit handled by Gustave Harrow.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was re-boxed by C. Spaeth in 1996. The collection was minimally processed and a finding aid created by Valerie Vanden Bossche in 2013 with funding provided by the Collections Care Pool Fund. Note that many of the original folders had unidentified numbers in addition to the master numbering system, these were transcribed exactly from the original folders.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Gustave Harrow legal records relating to the Estate of Mark Rothko, 1957-1986, undated. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in original numbered order; folder titles were transcribed exactly from original folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General files consists of documentation of both the Surrogate Court trial and the appeals. Included are correspondence, memos, affidavits, briefs, trial transcripts, depositions, examinations before trial, exhibits, motions, subpoenas, appendices, and hand-written notes. There are also reference materials including exhibition catalogs and valuation materials. Researchers may wish to consult Box 1 containing an index to general files in five card file boxes; there are also hand-written indices in the first folder of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 2 contains motions from pre-trial through the New York Supreme Court appeals. The documents are mostly photocopies. Indices are in the first folders of the series. Original sub-numbers were copied from original folders, although the significance of these is not immediately evident.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in original numbered order; folder titles were transcribed exactly from original folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 3 consists mostly of clippings of decision announcementss from New York Law Journal, Miscellaneous Reports and other sources. There are also copies of some decisions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 5 is comprised of post-trial files and other miscellaneous materials related to the case. Included are notes, clippings, correspondence, documents on fee arrangements, legal documents, and documents gathered together for the BBC documentary "The Rothko Conspiracy."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 6 contains clippings, correspondence, notes, and Gustave Harrow writings about the trial, including articles and a book entitled Art, the Artist, and the Consequences of Rothko: Lasting Legal Impressions from the Estate of a Great Artist.

did.unittitle: Book on Ethics - Rothko Source Material for Background
Clippings - The Sunday Sun, Baltimore MD - Spectator
Metropolitan Museum of Art / Annenberg Etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are reference materials assembled by Harrow for legal actions unrelated to the Rothko case. They include his researchabout the proposed Walter Annenberg gift of a communications center to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1976. Included are clippings and articles, Metropolitan Museum reports, notes, correspondence, and one sound cassette recording of the 3/14/1977 Metropolitan Museum of Art Board Meeting. The remainder of the materials concern various other issues at the museum, including administrative issues, challenges to the authenticity of certain pieces, the de Groot donation, the Packard Collection, and alleged misattributions in an Asian Art exhibition.
